{{otherships|HMS Hyacinth}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image | Ship image=[[File:Volage & Hyacinth in Chuenpee.jpg|300px|]] | Ship caption=''Hyacinth'' and {{HMS|Volage|1825|2}} engage Chinese war junks, 3 November 1839 }} {{Infobox ship career | Hide header= | Ship country=United Kingdom | Ship flag=[[File:Naval Ensign of the United Kingdom.svg|60px|Royal Navy Ensign]] | Ship name=HMS ''Hyacinth'' | Ship owner= | Ship ordered=10 June 1823 | Ship builder=[[HMNB Devonport|Plymouth Dockyard]] | Ship original cost=£17,361 including fitting<ref group=Note>A total cost accounting for inflation of approximately £{{formatnum:{{Inflation|UK|17361|1829|r=-2}}}} in today's money.</ref><ref name=RW/> | Ship laid down=March 1826 | Ship launched=6 May 1829 | Ship acquired= | Ship commissioned=12 January 1830 | Ship decommissioned= | Ship in service= | Ship out of service= | Ship renamed= | Ship struck= | Ship reinstated= | Ship honours= | Ship honors= | Ship captured= | Ship fate=*Coal hulk at Portland, November 1860 *Breaking completed in November 1871 | Ship status= | Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics | Hide header= | Header caption=<ref name=RW>Winfield (2004) p.118</ref> | Ship class={{sclass|Favorite|ship sloop}} | Ship tons burthen=429 <small>40/94</small> [[Builder's Old Measurement|bm]] | Ship length=*{{convert|109|ft|6|in|m|abbr=on|1}} (gundeck) *{{convert|86|ft|9+1/2|in|m|abbr=on|1}} (keel) | Ship beam={{convert|30|ft|9|in|m|abbr=on|1}} oa | Ship draught= | Ship draft= | Ship hold depth={{convert|12|ft|9|in|m|abbr=on|1}} | Ship propulsion= | Ship sail plan=[[Full-rigged ship]] | Ship complement=125 | Ship armament=*16 × 32-pounder [[carronade]]s *2 × 9-pounder [[chase gun|bow chasers]] *Reduced to 14 guns in 1848 | Ship notes= }} |} {{ external media | align = right | width = 258px | image1 = [http://www.nmm.ac.uk/collections/images/560/D/25/D2507_1.jpg A contemporary 1:60 full hull model of ''Hyacinth'' at the National Maritime Museum] }}
'''HMS ''Hyacinth''''' was an 18-gun [[Royal Navy]] [[Sloop-of-war|ship sloop]]. She was launched in 1829 and surveyed the north-eastern coast of Australia under [[Francis Price Blackwood]] during the mid-1830s. She took part in the [[First Opium War]], destroying, with [[HMS Volage (1825)|HMS ''Volage'']], 29 Chinese junks. She became a coal hulk at Portland in 1860 and was broken up in 1871.
==Design and construction== ''Hyacinth'' was the second of four {{sclass|Favorite|ship sloop}}s, which were a [[full-rigged ship|ship-rigged]] and lengthened version of the 1796 {{sclass|Cruizer|brig-sloop}}. All four ships of the class were ordered on 10 June 1823 and ''Hyacinth'' was laid down at [[HMNB Devonport|Plymouth Dockyard]] in March 1826. She was launched on 6 May 1829 and commissioned for the [[Jamaica Station (Royal Navy)|West Indies Station]] on 12 January 1830.<ref name=RW/>
===Dimensions=== ''Hyacinth'' measured {{convert|109|ft|6|in|m|abbr=on|1}} along the gun deck by {{convert|30|ft|9|in|m|abbr=on|1}} in the beam, and had a tonnage of 429 <small>40/94</small> [[Builder's Old Measurement|bm]].<ref name=RW/> She was flush-decked with a small forecastle and quarterdeck.
===Armament=== She was armed with sixteen 32-pounder [[carronade]]s and two 9-pounder [[chase gun|bow chaser guns]].<ref name=RW/>
==Service== <!--West Indies
Circa Feb 1833 recommissioned at Portsmouth.
Portsmouth 8 May 1833 Sailed for the East Indies.
1834/35 - Sydney - relieved ''Alligator''
Australia & New Zealand
''Anonymous Journal of a Voyage on board H.M.S. Hyacinth'' by [[Conrad Martens]]
''Hydrographical Remarks on the North-Eastern Coast of Australia'' by Blackwood
Portsmouth 19 Nov 1836 arrived from the East Indies.
Reviewed in October 1837 at Brighton with ''Emerald'' and 2 cutters by Queen Victoria in residence at the Pavilion.
28 Oct 1839 had arrived Hong Kong under Commander William Warren
See http://www.britishmedals.us/collections/GA/brady.html, http://www.archive.org/stream/royalnavyhistory06clow#page/280/mode/2up-->
During her 42-year career, she was stationed in the West and East Indies from 1829–41, took part in the First Opium War from 1841–42, and from 1843-46 was stationed off the west coast of Africa in the suppression of the slave trade. After being reduced to 14 guns in 1848,<ref name=RW/> she later became a coal hulk at [[Portsmouth]] before being broken up in 1871.<ref name=RW/>
